definition:
The Janko groups denoted by $J_1, J_2, J_3$, and $J_4$ are four of the
26 sporadic groups. They were discovered by . Janko in 1966 and
published in the article "A new finite simple group with abelian Sylow
$2$-subgroups and its characterization.” (Journal of Algebra, **3**,
1966, 32: 147-186).

Each of these groups have very intricate matrix representations as maps
into large general linear groups. For example, the matrix $K$
corresponding to $J_4$ gives a representation of $J_4$ in $GL_{112}(2)$.
